content.p: Sketch graphs to compute the limits below. You may use graphing software (i.e., Desmos).
Let f(x) = {{f}}. Use the definition of the derivative as a limit and your knowledge of some special trigonometric limits from the previous task to prove that

p.m: f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{ f(x+h) - f(x) }{h} = [\text{ ... insert your proof here ... }] = {{df}}

content.p: Use a calculator and a table of values to approximate the value of the limit below to three decimal places. Hint: since the limit is "two-sided", make sure your table accounts for h \to 0^+ and h \to 0^-.
Let g(x) = {{g}}. Use the definition of the derivative as a limit and your knowledge of some special trigonometric limits (involving the number e) to prove that

p.m: g'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{ g(x+h) - g(x) }{h} = [\text{ ... insert your proof here ... }] = {{dg}}
